hackathon-description-text: - Account from the Fort Worth tornado (pictured), and a friend who worked at that building in the picture, March 28, 2000:
hackathon-eligibility: Any individual or organization who is not directly involved with sponsoring or judging the Hackathon is invited to participate.  Companies with 50 or more employees are not eligible for a monetary prize.
hackathon-requirements:
You or your team must be registered in order to make a submission.  See the "How to Enter" section for more details.
The submission must be a unique invention or innovation that solves a problem, whether real or perceived, in the space of inclement weather prediction, reporting, news dissemination, and/or emergency management.  Some significant part of this invention must have been completed during the working period (4/20 - 5/4).  A functional product and/or slides are required to be demonstrated on Judging Day in order for a submission to be eligible.
You must own the intellectual property for the application you present, or have no conflicts with the owners of any intellectual property you use in developing your product, or have open-sourced it for all to use and share freely.
Please see the "Judging Criteria" for additional information on the properties of winning applications.

The object of this Contest is to create a product that solves a problem relating to the pursuit of predicting, spotting, and/or disseminating information about inclement weather, and/or disseminating information important to emergency responders and coordinators.  Entry eligibility will be determined using the criteria in section 5.  All eligible Entries received will be judged using the criteria in section 8, and the Panel will select one (1) best overall app winner, one (1) best weather-related app winner, and one (1) best emergency-related app winner.

This Contest starts at 2:00 PM Central Daylight Time on April 20, 2014 and ends at 2:00 PM Central Time May 4, 2014 (the “
 
”). Entries must be received within the Entry Period in accordance with the procedure set out in these Rules to be eligible for the Contest. Any submission received outside of the Entry Period will be automatically disqualified.
 

The Contest is open and offered to everyone with the exception of those directly involved with sponsoring or judging the Hackathon.  Companies with 50 or more people are not eligible to receive a monetary prize, but can still receive recognition.
All Entrants must register by 12:00 PM on May 4, 2014 with an intent to demonstrate a product at the Hackathon.  The intent must include the names of team member(s) and either a team name or name of the product.
The Contest is void in countries where otherwise prohibited or restricted by law.

You must also be physically present at the Dallas Makerspace building on May 4, 2014 at 2:00 PM Central time in order to present your demonstration.  There is no limit to the amount of Entries. The Entries will be judged one at a time upon delivery and performance of the product’s presentation.  The maximum allotted length of each presentation will be determined by how many teams are presenting, and will be announced at the start of judging.  Once submitted, an Entry cannot be cancelled.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: If there are no working project demonstrations, we will pick the best submitted idea and organize the resources in the Dallas Makerspace Civic Hacking Committee and other interested parties to implement the idea over the next several months.

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: The product must be resilient to network outages.  The part that actually operates in the area affected by the emergency should use a technology other than WiFi or mobile data to convey messages.

Did you solve a compelling challenge, or vastly improve a current solution?  Invent or innovate; don't just copy.  The problem addressed must also be within the realm of preparing for/tracking inclement weather and/or emergency management.

You are given 15 days to make something work, so take full advantage of the time!  It will be way more exciting to see your product in action than to just see slides about it.  It's also better to get a small piece working than nothing at all.

The solution should be easy and affordable for end users (be they cities or the public) to roll out.  For example, a $500 sensor network mesh will be better than a $50,000 radio antenna unless the way in which the end user harnesses the power of that mesh

hackathon-description-header: Dallas Makerspace's Civic Hacking Committee wants to help you create applications that will be *actually* useful in the event of a major telephone or power outage!
